moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. Nc3 dxc4 5. e4 Bb4 6. Bg5 c5 7. Bxc4 cxd4 8. Nxd4 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 Qa5 10. Bb5+ Nbd7 11. Bxf6 Qxc3+ 12. Kf1 gxf6 13. h4 a6 14. Rh3 Qa5 15. Be2 Ne5
comment:
#This came
a complete shock. The move is given as dubious in all the books which quote a
previus game from my opponent! That game (Maksimenko - Gyimesi 1997) continued
16.Qb3 b5 17.Qg3 Bd7 18.Qg7 Ke7 19.f4 Nc6 and White has a clear advantage.
Obviously my opponent must have an improvement, and the more I analysed this
game the less I trusted the line given in the books. I really didn't know what
to do in this position and eventually decided to centralise and hope!

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. Nc3 dxc4 5. e4 Bb4 6. Bg5 c5 7. Bxc4 cxd4 8. Nxd4 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 Qa5 10. Bb5+ Nbd7 11. Bxf6 Qxc3+ 12. Kf1 gxf6 13. h4 a6 14. Rh3 Qa5 15. Be2 Ne5 16. Qb3 b5 17. Rc3 Bd7 18. Rac1 O-O
comment:
A important decision. I had expected 18...Ke7 (with the idea of RHd8) 19.f4
Ng6 20.g3 which I thought was level, but my opponent thought was better for
White.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 d5 4. Nc3 dxc4 5. e4 Bb4 6. Bg5 c5 7. Bxc4 cxd4 8. Nxd4 Bxc3+ 9. bxc3 Qa5 10. Bb5+ Nbd7 11. Bxf6 Qxc3+ 12. Kf1 gxf6 13. h4 a6 14. Rh3 Qa5 15. Be2 Ne5 16. Qb3 b5 17. Rc3 Bd7 18. Rac1 O-O 19. Nf3 Qb6 20. Nxe5 fxe5 21. Qb4 Rac8 22. Rg3+ Kh8 23. Rd1 Qd8 24. Rgd3 Qxh4 25. Rh3 Qd8 26. Qd2
comment: and Black resigned because he must lose at least a piece.
